contents.context:
LG Chem is taking all available measures possible to protect everyone affected by the latest gas leak at its Polymers plant in India by cooperating with Indian authorities and the Korean Embassy in New Delhi.
That's according to South Korea's largest chemical company as it denied media reports that there was a second leak at the plant.
Both Indian authorities and LG Chem confirmed that the latest evacuation was precautionary out of concern that rising temperatures at the plant's gas tank could possibly cause another leak.
At least 11 people have been confirmed dead and hundreds more have been hospitalized after a chemical gas leak at a plant owned by LG Polymers, a subsidiary of the South Korean megacorporation LG in Andhra Pradesh state early Thursday.
Reporter : jychoi@arirang.com

No additional leak around India LG Chem plant confirmed, wider evacuation was a preventive measur

contents.context:
A deadly gas leak at an LG Polymers plant in southern India on Thursday has killed at least 11 people. Around a thousand people were admitted to hospital, and about 20 of those are in a critical condition.
An official from Andhra Pradesh State where the incident occurred said on Friday that those seriously ill include 10 children and the death toll is likely to rise.
On the second day since the chemical gas leak, more people are being evacuated from nearby villages within 3.5 kilometers of the site of the leak.
Three thousand people were evacuated on Thursday, but authorities did not say how many more have been evacuated on Friday.
There were also false reports that the wider evacuation orders were due to a second leak at the factory.
But Seoul-based LG Chem said that it is just a precautionary measure in case tank temperatures rise and cause another leak.
The company said it is pouring water into the tank and doing what it can to keep temperatures under control and it pledged to ensure that casualties receive treatment quickly.
Authorities said the gas leak had largely subsided.

"I also underline that we will be there till that leakage is totally plugged and other measures to neutralize the entire chemical situation there is also being taken. So overall the situation is under control and I think overall we can say that now it is a question of rehabilitation and treatment of the people who have been affected."

A tank of styrene gas that had been unattended for a long time due to the COVID-19 lockdown in the country is suspected to be the source of the leak.
Hong Yoo, Arirang News.
Reporter : yoohong@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Evacuation area around India LG Chem plant widened after deadly gas leak

contents.context:
India woke up to a toxic gas leakage on Thursday, leaving at least 11 people dead, including an eight-year-old child, as well as hundreds more who were rushed to hospital.
The accident occurred in India's Andhra Pradesh state at a plant operated by LG Polymers, a unit of South Korea's biggest petrochemical maker LG Chemical.
Most of the victims lost consciousness while driving or standing on balconies outside their homes.
The leakage during the early hours of the morning also gassed people as they slept.
The toxic gas has been identified as Styrene, a flammable liquid that's heated into a gas to make industrial products like rubber and latex.
The gas reportedly leaked after being heated at the factory.
Around a thousand people were directly exposed and around 3-thosuand people in the contaminated area were evacuated.
The gas leak was later sealed and the air gradually cleared.


"And other measures to neutralize the entire chemical situation there is also being taken. So overall, the situation is under control."

No South Korean victims were reported.
In a statement released from Seoul, LG Chemical said the gas can cause nausea and dizziness when inhaled and it pledged to ensure the casualties receive treatment quickly.
Praying for safety for all affected, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi also said the government is reviewing rescue and relief operations.
The tragedy comes after the plant reopened following India's national lockdown that was imposed in late March due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Kim Dami, Arirang News.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Gas leak at LG plant in India kills 11, hundreds hospitalized

contents.context:
Jobless claims continued to swell in the U.S. last week due to COVID-19.
The Labor Department said Thursday that new filings for unemployment insurance hit almost 3.17 million last week.
U.S. media say over 33-million people have lost their jobs during the past seven weeks.
That's the highest number of job losses since the Labor Department began collecting data for jobless claims in 1967.
In the meantime, 113-year-old luxury department store Neiman Marcus filed for bankruptcy on Thursday due to mounting debt amid the pandemic.
The high-end brand closed its 43 stores, and most of its 14-thousand workers were put on furlough.

"It's really the timing of it is interesting because we're in a very difficult period in our economy. And these stores that have been allowed to stay open for a while, may not have the means to do it anymore."

The coronavirus impact is hitting the European economy as well.
France has seen its industrial production fall by over 16 percent in March from the previous month.
The construction and transportation sectors were hit particularly hard, but production in the medicine sector jumped over 15 percent.
The European Commission has warned of an economic shock not seen since the Great Depression, saying the Eurozone's GDP could shrink by a record 7.7 percent this year.
Yoon Jung-min, Arirang News.
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Unemployment insurance filings in U.S. hit 3.17 mil. last week

At least eleven people have died and a thousand others have been hospitalized in India after a toxic gas leak Thursday from a chemical plant owned by South Korea's LG.
The factory in southern part of the country, manufactures polymers used to make plastics for the South Korean firm.
The facility had been shut down since mid-March following India's strict nationwide lockdown, and was expected to restart operations this week as the country begins to lift restrictions.
Local officials say the gas spread throughout a three-kilometer radius, and nearly 15-hundred families living in the vicinity were evacuated.

We begin a discussion on an issue making headlines.
Globally speaking, COVID-19 now has infected more than three.five million people.
The U.S. has the highest number of reported infections, as thousands are still being infected daily.
For some people who get Covid-19, the symptoms are limited to a cough or a fever. But others experience extreme pain and discomfort, including strong aches and shortness of breath.
With hospitals overwhelmed as they are, many infected have to fend for themselves -- and recovery time can take several days to weeks.
Today we speak with a Washington state resident who recovered from the virus -- to hear about what it was like for her and her husband, Chris -- and what we can do to support those who have the virus.
Susan Kingsbury Kane. Thank you for joining us.


First, walk us through how your husband initially became infected. What made you suspect you caught the virus?


How did the virus affect you physically? Which symptoms did you find the most difficult to cope with?


It must have been an upsetting time. How did you feel emotionally, especially with your husband being so ill at the same time?



Your husband was in critical condition after getting COVID-19. Thankfully he has fully recovered now. How did his condition worsen and what kind of medical support did he need?


It was a very trying time for your family, and a lot to get used to in daily life. Self-quarantining is basically social isolation from your loved ones as well as from work. How did this affect your emotions?


In what ways do you think government workers or the medical system could support infected patients better?

We've heard reports of some people relapsing after getting better. Did you have any lingering symptoms or worry you may go through the same experience?


It's always encouraging to know that people are thinking about us in times of illness. What was encouraging for you and what can family members, friends, and the community best support those people with COVID-19?

I believe you and your husband have been trying to help others recover from the virus as well. What have you been doing to support others -- and do you have any words of advice for those who are infected?

That's all we have time for today but it's been wonderful and so encouraging to speak with you Susan.
Thanks for joining the programme today.
(Seattle, U.S.)
Reporter : osy@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Infection to Recovery: Handling daily life with COVID-19

contents.context:
Starting in mid-April, states in the U.S. have moved to ease lockdowns and reopen the economy as President Trump announced guidelines based on three phases.

"A prolonged lockdown, combined with a forced economic depression, would inflict an immense and wide-ranging toll on public health."

The guidelines include keeping good personal hygiene and ensuring social distancing.
And as states succeed in going through the three phases without a surge of COVID-19 patients, they can allow more travel and public interaction.
According to CNN, 43 out of 50 states will have reopened in part by the end of this week.
In California, some stores like flower shops and bookstores will open and Mississippi will allow gatherings of over 20 people.
However, there are concerns on whether this is the right time for the U.S. to ease lockdowns.
President Trump himself, in an interview with ABC News on Tuesday, acknowledged that the death toll could rise as the U.S. reopens its economy.
Experts in the U.S. point out there haven't been enough safety measures and a number of states have not satisfied the conditions required to lift their lockdowns for example, seeing new cases drop for 14 consecutive days.
A public poll by the Washington Post suggests 82-percent of American citizens oppose the reopening of movie theaters and 78-percent are against sports facilities reopening.
According to the U.S. Department of Health, the number of confirmed cases in the U.S. has surpassed 126-thousand and the death toll is almost 71-thousand, the highest in the world.
Oh Jung-hee, Arirang News.
Reporter : jhlucyoh@arirang.com

The Center-right opposition party The Republicans urged France to use South Korea as a role model, and praised the Korean public's community spirit.

Russia has been reporting over 10-thousand new cases a day for the past four consecutive days, with its accumulated number of cases at over 165-thousand as of Wednesday.
Russia's culture minister has also been diagnosed with COVID-19 , the fourth top Russian official to have contracted the virus.
The UK has now leapfrogged Italy to have the highest number of COVID-19 deaths in Europe, with its death toll surpassing the 30-thousand mark.
German Chancellor Angela Merkel said Wednesday that the country had passed the first phase of the pandemic, and shops will be allowed to open.
She explained that the public will be required to maintain social distancing until June 5th, but added the country's football league Bundesliga will restart in mid-May with no spectators, becoming Europe's first major league to resume.

Speaking at a press conference in Washington on Wednesday, U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo reaffirmed the U.S. has significant evidence the COVID-19 virus originated from a certain laboratory in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

"We don't have certainty. And there is significant evidence that this came from the laboratory. Those statements can both be true. "

Two laboratories were researching coronavirus in Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak, before the pandemic started.
The theory that COVID-19 might've come from there was given further traction last week when President Trump suggested he was confident the Wuhan Institute of Virology was the origin.
The WHO says it's waiting on an invitation from China to take part in its investigation into the animal origins of the virus that was first reported in Wuhan in December 2019.
However, Beijing's UN ambassador in Geneva says Beijing's top priority is first beating the pandemic, then countering what he called an "absurd and ridiculous" accusation from the U.S.
The Chinese Foreign Ministry also accused Washington of engaging what it called political manipulation.

"We are opposed to individual politicians in the United States conducting investigations based on the presumption of guilt on China for domestic political reasons. We are opposed to using the epidemic to engage in political manipulation."

Beijing says President Trump and Pompeo's allegations about the source of the virus are simply them trying to "shift responsibility" over their failed response to the outbreak in the U.S.
Lee Seung-jae, Arirang News.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com

Significant evidence China hid truth about origins of COVID-19: Pompeo

The European Union's economy is on track to contract by 7.4 percent this year following the global COVID-19 pandemic, shrinking at a higher rate than during the Great Recession in the 1930s.
The European Commission said Wednesday that investment is expected to collapse while unemployment rates and deficits are to skyrocket.
It forecasts that Italy, one of the hardest hit countries of the virus, will see its economy shrink by 9.5 percent, while significant damage is also expected for Spain and Greece, countries that depend heavily on tourism.
Unemployment in the 19 eurozone countries will increase to 9.6 percent this year, and slowly decline to 7.9 percent in 2021.
